Award.AbstractNarration:
As the world is becoming increasingly interconnected through economic ties, political ties, and the internet, cross-cultural understanding is ever more important, and the consequences of cross-cultural misunderstanding are ever more dangerous. On a day-to-day basis, culture is reflected and transmitted through the experience of ordinary situations; the analysis of such daily experience provides an important and heretofore underutilized potential route towards better understanding of the ways in which cultures are similar or different. The present project seeks to assess the daily experience of people in 40 countries around the world, associating such experiences with cross-cultural differences in personality, economics, populations, and values.

The findings of this research will shed new light on an under-researched, but fundamental issue for cross-cultural psychology and, even more broadly, psychology as a whole: how situations are related to personality and behavior. In previous research, the investigator, David Funder (University of California, Riverside) developed an international, multiple language version of the Riverside Situational Q-sort (RSQ) in which individuals assess real-world situations that they encounter by sorting 89 descriptive features along the degree to which each is characteristic or uncharacteristic. The proposed research adapts this Q-sort methodology for wide-spread international collaboration, by creating a freely available, flexible, and multilingual open-source website for collecting data about situations. Via international collaborators, participants in 40 countries will be recruited to complete the RSQ in their own language; they will also describe their behavior in the situation, and, separately, complete personality assessments. Using this novel and unique method for the comprehensive cross-cultural comparison of situational experience, the project will examine whether situations are an important active ingredient of culture and will test a variety of research questions regarding cross-cultural similarities and differences in ordinary situations. This project will have important implications for understanding intercultural relations and managing cultural diversity in a world where increasing numbers of individuals with different cultural backgrounds share situations with each other.

Co-funding from the Office of International Science and Engineering (OISE) provided support for this award.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The International Situations Project

Culture is both reflected and transmitted through the daily experience of ordinary situations. However, psychological research has traditionally paid more attention to the conceptualization and measurement of persons than of situations, an imbalance that extends to cross-cultural psychology. Our project aims to help remedy this imbalance. It is guided by the idea that attributes of situational experience are active ingredients of culture.

The Project

The International Situations Project is a world-wide collaboration of 141 psychological researchers in 65 countries (see map). We worked with our international colleagues to carefully translate all of the research materials into 43 languages, ranging from Icelandic to Arabic to Marathi Hindi.

Participants provided data via a custom-built website that operates in all of these languages, using an instrument we developed, the Riverside Situational Q-sort, to describe their experience of an ordinary situation the previous day. They also provided demographic and personality data, including the BFI-2, which measures the Big Five personality traits (Extraversion, Emotional Stability, Conscientiousness, Agreeableness, Openness). Data collection was largely completed in the summer of 2018.  It was resumed at a few sites (including the US) in 2020, to allow comparison of pre-pandemic and experience with experiences during the ongoing COVID-19 crisis.

 Results (so far)

To date, the following findings have been reported in articles that have been published or are currently under review. Further analyses are ongoing.

 Situational experience around the world: A replication and extension in 62 countries.

Compares the findings of the earlier "World at 7" project, which examined situational experience in 20 countries, with the results of our newer project in 62 countries. Replicated findings: Average situational experience around the world is mildly positive; the same countries were equivalently similar to each other in both studies; homogeneity of experience was greater within than between countries, though the difference was small. Not replicated: The earlier finding that negative aspects of experience vary more across countries than positive aspects.

 International optimism: Correlates and consequences of dispositional optimism across 61 countries.

Assessed dispositional optimism and its correlates around the world. Perhaps surprisingly, country-level optimism was negatively related to gross domestic product per capita, population density, and democratic norms and positively related to income inequality and perceived corruption. However, country-level optimism was positively related to projected economic improvement. Individual-level optimism was positively related to individual well-being within every country, although this relationship was less strong in countries with challenging economic and social circumstances.

 The experience of situations before and during a COVID-19 shelter-at-home period.

Undergraduate participants rated their experience of an ordinary daily situation before and during a COVID-19 shelter-at-home period. Situational descriptors placed higher before the sheltering period included "new relationships could develop," "femininity can be expressed," and "talking is expected or demanded." Items placed higher during the sheltering period included "family is important," and "people are disagreeing about something." Shelter-at-home conditions accentuated the importance of family, could lead to conflict, and limited ordinary opportunities for social interaction. Agreeableness was associated with the overall positivity of experience at both time periods; other traits varied in their relevance as the situation changed.

 Economic status and situational experience of individuals and nations: A 62-country study.

Individuals' self-reports of economic status were significantly associated with individual positive experience. Countries' economic status, measured by the Human Development Index, were even more strongly related to national average positive situational experience. The almost equivalent patterns of associations between specific aspects of experience and economic status powerfully illustrated how similar situational experiences are associated with national as well as individual economic status.

 Who in the world is trying to change their personality traits? Volitional personality change among college students in 56 countries.

More than 13,000 participants from 56 countries using 42 different languages reported whether they were currently trying to change their personality and, if so, what they were trying to change. Around the world, 61.79% of participants reported that they are currently trying to change their personalities, with the highest percentage in Thailand (84.04%) and the lowest in Kenya (21.58%). Of those trying to change, the most common goals were increases in emotional stability (32.06%), conscientiousness (18.25%), extraversion (15.15%), and agreeableness (13.99%). Individuals who are trying to change any personality trait tend to have relatively low levels of emotional stability and happiness.

 Happiness around the world: A combined etic-emit approach across 63 countries.

We assessed the cross-cultural applicability of a measure of independent happiness developed in the US and a measure of interdependent happiness developed in Japan, with data from 63 countries representing 7 sociocultural regions. Results indicate that independent happiness was most coherent in western, European countries. Reliabilities of both happiness measures were lowest in African and Middle Eastern countries, suggesting that the traditional "east vs. west" conceptualization of culture neglects important regions of the world.
